message_1: What is the enthalpy change of the reaction when 2 moles of HCl reacts with 1 mole of Ca(OH)2 to produce 1 mole of CaCl2 and 2 moles of H2O, given that the enthalpy change of formation for Ca(OH)2 is -986 kJ/mol, the enthalpy change of formation for CaCl2 is -732 kJ/mol, and the enthalpy change of formation for HCl and H2O are -92.32 kJ/mol and -241.82 kJ/mol, respectively?
message_2:
To calculate the enthalpy change of the reaction, we can use the formula:

ΔH_reaction = Σ ΔH_f(products) - Σ ΔH_f(reactants)

where ΔH_f is the enthalpy change of formation for each compound.

For the reactants, we have 1 mole of Ca(OH)2 and 2 moles of HCl:
Σ ΔH_f(reactants) = (-986 kJ/mol)(1 mol Ca(OH)2) + (-92.32 kJ/mol)(2 mol HCl) = -986 - 184.64 = -1170.64 kJ

For the products, we have 1 mole of CaCl2 and 2 moles of H2O:
Σ ΔH_f(products) = (-732 kJ/mol)(1 mol CaCl2) + (-241.82 kJ/mol)(2 mol H2O) = -732 - 483.64 = -1215.64 kJ

Now, we can calculate the enthalpy change of the reaction:
ΔH_reaction = Σ ΔH_f(products) - Σ ΔH_f(reactants) = -1215.64 kJ - (-1170.64 kJ) = -45 kJ

The enthalpy change of the reaction is -45 kJ.
